page.title: 06Fuel
page.content: Our area lies on the edge of important peat deposits and most families cut peat.Each family has its separate peat bank for which they pay the hill owner about Â£5 yearly.Farmers own their own banks. First the heather is removed from the top of the bank. This is called 'flaying'and a special big knife is used for this purpose. Of the two people needed to cut peat,one uses a special tool called a'tusker' to slice off the peat and his helper lifts out the peat with a fork and stacks it on the bank. Soon the peats are spread out flat on the heather to dry.Two weeks later they are raised into little heaps. When they are dry enough they are carted home.Some people are experimenting with special peat cutting machines which produce peat by squeezing them out through holes with hydraulic rams.
